intro: Scirpus ciliatifolius, commonly known as the hairy-fringed sedge, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to wetland environments in North America. It typically grows in marshes, swamps, and along the edges of ponds and lakes. The plant has narrow, grass-like leaves that are often covered with fine, hair-like structures, giving it its common name. Its flowering spikes are usually tall and cylindrical, producing small, three-lobed flowers. Scirpus ciliatifolius plays an important role in wetland ecosystems by stabilizing soil and providing habitat for various aquatic and terrestrial organisms.
